metadata.title: The START (Surgical Triage And Resource Allocation Tool) of Surgical Prioritisation during the COVID-19 Pandemic

body_text.text: It is imperative that surgeons consider broader resource utilisation and allocation, beyond individual patients’ needs. Doctors are trained to consider disease severity as the most important factor in prioritising treatment. Yet, in a pandemic, considering overall resource utilisation is essential.

Each country exists at different timepoints on their pandemic curves. Blanket recommendations for postponing all elective surgeries would be relevant in resource-scarce states, but inefficient in resource-sufficient states. Dynamic resource allocation decision-making is necessary.

The COVID-19 pandemic would likely be prolonged, with unpredictable waves of infection. Hospitals need to balance risks of overloading current capacity, versus the inevitable backlog of deferred cases. Mismanagement of demand and supply would lead to unsustainable deferment of services, excessive built-up demand, causing an overly protracted recovery.

START is an easily-administered and highly-adaptable tool for surgical prioritisation, developed by our tertiary academic centre. The START Score is derived from the Surgical Triage (ST) and Resource Utilisation (RU) Scores of each case (Table 1
).
body_text.section: Overview of the Surgical Triage And Resource Allocation Tool (START)

body_text.text: The ST Score is dependent on an intuitive colour-coded 5-tier system (Life-threatening/Emergency, Oncologically/Organ-Threatening Urgent, Oncologically/Organ-threatening Semi-urgent, Elective, and Non-essential. We classified Urology surgeries (Table 1) based on consensus opinion from an expert panel of subspecialists. The ST Score was designed to be incremental (Score=2n), to ensure cases in each Tier will not have a higher final START score (and lower priority) than the following less-acute Tier, unless the surgery would be highly resource-intensive with all four key resources utilised. As Life-threatening cases were intentionally assigned a score of 0, the START score of all emergency cases would be 0, indicating the default highest priority, regardless of the RU score.
body_text.section: Overview of the Surgical Triage And Resource Allocation Tool (START)

body_text.text: The RU Score is determined by four hospital resources that are scarce in the COVID-19 pandemic. These were the need for Intensive/High-Dependency Care, hospital stay > 2-days, involvement of other medical/surgical disciplines, and blood transfusions. For every resource consumed, a cumulative score is derived by multiplying the multiplication factors which applies.
body_text.section: Overview of the Surgical Triage And Resource Allocation Tool (START)

body_text.text: The ST score is multiplied by the RU score to calculate the final START score. START scores range from 0 to 16.3. Lower START scores indicate more urgent and less resource intense cases, which should be accorded higher priorities. START proved effective with table-top-exercises based on different scenarios. Its ease of administration reduces stress associated with complex decision-making during the pandemic. It is also highly-applicable to other surgical disciplines. With any given amount of resources, and as local pandemic situations change, surgeons can prioritise surgeries based on START scores. It is our hope that sharing this easily-administered tool would enable Urologists worldwide to dynamically prioritise surgeries, tailored to their local prevailing pandemic circumstances.
body_text.section: Overview of the Surgical Triage And Resource Allocation Tool (START)
